instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to map forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in two forest reserves in Myanmar?
Output: Classical and short-wave infrared bands (B2, B3, B4, B11, and B12) were used for mapping forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in two forest reserves in Myanmar.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the algorithmic performances to map forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in two forest reserves in Myanmar, and how accurate were the predictions compared to field-based measurements?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the algorithmic performances in predicting aboveground biomass (AGB) was the coefficient of determination (R-2) and the root mean square error (RMSE). 

The accuracy of the predictions compared to field-based measurements varied depending on the forest reserve. For the Namhton forest reserve, the RF-based ordinary Kriging (RFOK) model had an R-2 value of 0.47 and an RMSE value of 0.52 AGB t/ha. For the Yinmar forest reserve, the RF-based co-Kriging (RFCK) model had an R-2 value of 0.91 and an RMSE value of 34.72 AGB t/ha. 

Overall, the predictions were relatively accurate, with the RF-based co-Kriging model performing better in terms of R-2 value and the RF-based ordinary Kriging model having a lower RMSE value.

instruction: What machine learning algorithms were used in the related study to link the spectral data with field-based aboveground biomass (AGB) measurements and determine the spatial distribution of AGB in the two forest reserves in Myanmar?
Output: The machine learning algorithms used in the related study to link the spectral data with field-based aboveground biomass (AGB) measurements and determine the spatial distribution of AGB in the two forest reserves in Myanmar were random forest (RF) and stochastic gradient boosting (SGB).

instruction: How does the use of textural measures from wavelet analysis and VIs from Sentinel-2 compare to traditional methods in predicting forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in the two forest reserves in Myanmar?
Output:
The use of textural measures from wavelet analysis and vegetation indices (VIs) from Sentinel-2 showed strong predictive power in estimating forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in the two forest reserves in Myanmar. These methods outperformed traditional methods in predicting AGB.

The study found that textural measures produced from wavelet analysis and VIs from Sentinel-2 were the strongest predictors for AGB in the evergreen forest reserve (Namhton). On the other hand, spectral bands and VIs showed the highest sensitivity in predicting AGB in the deciduous forest reserve (Yinmar).

To establish the predictive models, the study utilized random forest (RF) and stochastic gradient boosting (SGB) algorithms to statistically link the spectral and topographic parameters derived from Sentinel-2 and Shuttle Radar Topographic Mission (SRTM) data with field-based AGB measurements. The RF and SGB algorithms were found to be effective in estimating AGB.

Furthermore, the study employed RF-based Kriging models to improve the accuracy of AGB estimation. The fitted models were RF-based ordinary Kriging (RFOK) for Namhton forest reserve and RF-based co-Kriging (RFCK) for Yinmar forest reserve.
